contentrichtext.text: [[File:Wormleighton Manor2.jpg|thumb|Wormleighton Manor]] '''Wormleighton''' is a [[village]] in the [[county]] of [[Warwickshire]], [[England]]. The village was abandoned after the [[English Civil War]] when the [[Spencer family]] home [[Wormleighton Manor]] was burned down in 1645. The village, however, refounded in the 19th century. Sites of interest also include a 12th-century church. The first mention of a [[post office]] in the village is in September 1853, when a type of [[postmark]] known as an undated circle was issued.<ref>''The Undated Circular Marks of the Midland Counties'', p. 151. (1997). The Midland (GB) Postal History Society. ISBN 0-9513311-3-2.</ref> The post office closed in 1971. The historic family of Wormleighton is based in the North West of England. During World War II, Captain Ronald fought with distinction and was awarded the Victoria Cross in 1944. The Spencer family fortune derived from its earliest known ancestor, Sir John Spencer of Wormleighton, Warwickshire, who bought [[Althorp]] in 1522 with the huge profits from his sheep-rearing business. His descendants include the [[Earl Spencer|Earls Spencer]] and [[Winston Churchill]]. In 1498 an inquest jury<ref>Public Records Office, C43/28 File 14.</ref> recorded that 60 villagers had been evicted from the Wormleighton Estate "weeping, to wander in idleness ... perished of hunger".<ref>''A Social History of England 1200-1500'' p126 edited by Rosemary Horrox and W.
